chapter.title: Conventions
chapter.para: &ib; documentation conforms to the following conventions:

entry.para: Command names and options, subcommand names, function names, path names, file names, and URLs are in a fixed-width font.
Variables and other replaceable text are in italics.
Text that a user actively enters is bold and fixed width.
A newly-introduced term is in italics.
Syntax elements that are required are in curly brackets.
Syntax elements that are optional are in square brackets.
The HTML or XML element (or tag) is in angle brackets; the name of an HTML or XML element is not in angle brackets.
A pipe denotes a logical OR within syntax.

chapter.title: Organization
chapter.para: It is often easier to organize a document after you have ample content. "Let the data do the organizing."

section.title: Chapter versus section
section.para: If you chunk information into smaller parts, write an introductory sentence or paragraph. If you find it difficult to write that introduction, your organizational structure might be bloated; you might have a section or subsection that you can remove.

chapter.title: Lists
chapter.para: If you use a list, include more than one list item. If you only have one list item, remove the list and rephrase the information using one or two sentences. Doing so removes unnecessary structure. Use only one type of list at a time; avoid * foo: A tool that ..., where * signifies an unordered list and : signifies a definition list.

section.title: Definition
section.para: Use an definition (or variable) list for complementary information that includes a term and a definition.

section.title: Ordered
section.para: Use an ordered (or numbered) list for information that needs to be performed in a particular order. If only part of the list needs to be performed in a particular order, write a default order that you want your reader to use.

section.title: Unordered
section.para: Use an unordered (or bulleted) list for information that does not need to be performed in a particular order.

chapter.title: Numbers
chapter.para: Generally, single-digit numbers are spelled out. For example, one, two, three, or 10, 11, 12. For details about how to be most clear when writing technical content that includes numbers, see Writing Numbers.

chapter.title: Parts of speech
chapter.para: For terms such as set up, setup, and set-up, examine the underlying parts of speech:

chapter.title: Shortened text
chapter.para: An acronym (or an initialism) is pronounced as a word (or a series of letters), and is a short version of an expanded set of terms. For the sake of simplicity, the term acronym is used in &ib; documentation.

If an acronym is unfamiliar to the reader, expand it first and put the acronym in parentheses as in Simple File Transfer Protocol (SFTP). If an acronym is familiar to the reader, expand it in parentheses after the acronym as in SFTP (Simple File Transfer Protocol).

note.para: To avoid insulting your reader, do not expand an acronym if it is used on a regular basis.

chapter.para: Expand abbreviations, such as e.g., because they add complexity for non-native readers, are used inconsistently, and are unnecessary.

chapter.title: Titles
chapter.para: Title styles differ depending on where they are used. To avoid typos, consider using entities, such as &sa;, for section names that are frequently used. To be consistent, leave out trailing colons within titles if they cannot be inserted systematically.

listitem.para: For a book, use a title that provides enough context. For example, &ib; technical documentation: Style guide clarifies that the style guide is about technical documentation rather than legal documentation, and &ib; specifies that it is derived from Infobits rather than another entity.

For a chapter or section, use a title that provides enough context without being redundant. In a chapter titled Lists, for example, use section titles Ordered and Unordered rather than Ordered list and Unordered list.

For procedure titles, use a gerund (also known as a verb with an -ing ending), such as Writing in the example that follows. Doing so keeps the procedure name short, and distinguishes the name of a procedure from its steps that are in the imperative form.
